pullRequest.title: [RW-5418][RW-5754] UpdateRuntime UI
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description:
I've found that anything that touches the RuntimeStore to be pretty fragile so stuff related to that warrants an extra look, especially the useCustomRuntime function, https://github.com/all-of-us/workbench/pull/4281/files#diff-f53435d20207d854b5a65f4be0494bbeb1390492c2f4a1ac7226b5f90453931dR347, that sends out the API calls.
Example of an update that requires "Next" confirmation

Example of an update that can execute right away


PR checklist

 This PR meets the Acceptance Criteria in the JIRA story
 The JIRA story has been moved to Dev Review
 This PR includes appropriate unit tests
 I have run and tested this change locally
 I have run the E2E tests on ths change against my local UI + API server with yarn test-local
 If this includes a UI change, I have taken screen recordings or screenshots of the new behavior and notified the PO and UX designer
 If this includes an API change, I have updated the appropriate Swagger definitions and notified API consumers
 If this includes a new feature flag, I have created and linked new JIRA tickets to (a) turn on the feature flag and (b) remove it later

commit.message: bit messy but the diff calc shoudl be correct
WIP - can calculate diffs along with textual descriptions
merge + adding cost estimator to confirmation page
calling the actual updateRuntime API in the right scenarios
add first test - sending out delete on needs_delete
cannot make buttons into function components

nodes.bodyText: lol, I called this something different, so whoever merges first is going to cause a conflict for the other person. this is a better name than mine though.
pickMainDiskSize isn't async so this won't do anything
There's already a waitOneTickAndUpdate in pickDropdownOption, which is called by pickComputeType - if that needs an extra tick then put the call inside pickDropdownOption
likewise, if this is necessary after pickMainDiskSize then it should be incorporated into pickNumberInput
opt: it is possibly worth making a 'click button by aria-label' function a la mustClickCreateButton, especially since you use this multiple times
nit: use 'should' language
What does this name mean?
Does this interact strangely with the call on L374?
Hm, how is this one not exported, but getRuntimeConfigDiffs is? Isn't this backwards?

nit: A tree structure of these functions might be slightly easier to follow here IMO. e.g.
compareRuntimeConfigs():
  return [...compareMachines(), ...compareCompute(), ...compareDataproc()]

compareMachines():
  return [compareCpu(), compareMemory()]

etc...
There's a good amount of duplication between some of these, e.g. standard and preemtible where you could probably share most of the implementation and just pass an extra label through

Do you have clarity around what the product behavior should be when someone switches from GCE -> Dataproc?
Is it supposed to show the new worker machine type as part of the diff? Or no?
nit: most of the existing functions in here use const foo = () => {} style. Would probably match this for consistency.
Running -> Updating?
Is this guaranteed to happen? How long does this actually take, and is it possible we won't observe this?

If we have to do this approach (we should check with Leo to understand whether this is expected and whether the behavior can be changed), I think we would also want to have some kind of upper bound timer here. e.g. also check for time having elapsed at this point

nit: I'd characterize this as test, fake, or stub data rather than a mock. Generally I prefer reserving the term mock to refer to actual  testing mocks to avoid confusion.
opt: IN this case, I might just name it defaultGceConfig to match the other naming below
hm. Why is this the result? Please comment if it's needed
I would shallow copy here. I made defaultRuntime a function to avoid tests interfering with one another by mutating the runtime value.
nice..
nit: 6 dots? Is this in the mocks? I'd say no more than 3, if we need ellipses at all here.
I don't think "Number" should be capitalized here. Not sure whether this matches the mocks or not - if it does, happy to make my objection to Lou and/or Shimon
They only had a few examples specified. I changed the casing for all of the diffs to be lowercase except for "CPUs".

The mocks actually do have an example of going from GCE -> Dataproc and it doesn't have the new Dataproc config in the diff but I'll ping Shimon and Lou since I think it would be useful to add.
However, even if we want that feature, I'm thinking we should address it in a different ticket to reduce the scope of the current PR.

I actually started out with a more reusable approach but I found that the current implementation is easier to work with and think about since every "diff" maps to a single function. IMO, the lower complexity is worth the extra verbosity.
not sure if I did quite what you were looking for but I split it up into two lists

I export getRuntimeConfigDiffs because the RuntimeConfig object is easier to use in the UI. The Runtime diff function was actually only created because I don't have access to the RuntimeConfig object within the useCustomRuntime so I had to find a way to map between the two.
Not sure. In practice, I've only seen it go right to Stopping but Updating is probably the right behavior. I'll reach out to Terra to ask about what the expected behavior here is.
I did this so that it reflects what's currently happening in the product. Could be a bug so I'll reach out to Terra to see what's going on.
nit: revert
Please also restore timers here:     jest.useRealTimers();
I'm a bit confused by this helper. It looks like it's just getting the input value, and it's identical to getNumberInput - would probably merge these together and just call it getInputValue
hmm.. why does this and the next test require deletion? Changing the machine type shouldn't require it
These two act statements shouldn't be needed, but also - should be able to use your helper function mustClickButton here

opt: IMO it is cleaner to just check the resulting value in the runtimeApiStub.runtime here, rather than using mocks/spies - but maybe this is not realistic if you don't have any detectable immediate changes in the fake as a result of applying an update
Here it should be possible to just check the Deleting status on the runtime

What I was more suggesting is that you break the uniformity of these function signatures, so that they more directly interact with the values they care about. For example, this method maybe something like:
[
  compareComputeTypes(oldRuntime.computeType, newRuntime.computeType),
  compareMachineCpu(oldRuntime.machine.cpu, ...)
]

This way the lower level functions are a bit more tightly scoped.
I would also put the filtering up one level so you don't need to duplicate it
nit: indentation

This is big enough that I'd probably just define a private function component here, e.g. see ConfirmPolicy, CreatePanel. I realize you don't get the benefits of the closure, but there's a lot of local state in this function, so defining explicit inputs is probably a positive.
You should be able to pass a component as a prop, e.g. for the next/create/update buttons, as I'm guessing this is the main concern.
<ConfirmUpdate
  updateButton={renderUpdateButton()}
  ... />
The update API supports changing the machine type, so why does this require a delete?
The create button from the Create panel is supposed to close the panel (by invoking onUpdate), may have been lost in the merge conflicts

Huh - wait. This actually isn't clear in the mocks, but I thought that the confirmation page would appear in all cases (whether this was an update OR a delete/recreate). I don't feel strongly on this though, did you discuss this point with Lou / Shimon already?
This can be a follow-up, but I would have thought that the message here would be different in the update vs delete case.
This needs to be disabled inthe same manner as the update button

commit.message: Always go to Next confirmation panel. Show different warning message depending on type of changes

nodes.bodyText:
Ah, I was basing this off the behavior that I observed in the Terra application but I misinterpreted what I was seeing. There, changing the CPU/memory requires the "Next" workflow even though the cluster does not need to be recreated.
It looks like they have 3 different UIs depending on the kind of change you are making.

Update with no warning (for changes that do not require even a reboot?)
Next/Update with a reboot warning
Next/Update with loss of data warning

In my implementation, I only have two different UIs and I grouped the latter two together whereas I should have grouped the first two.

I see. I kind of like having the uniform function signature since it offloads the logic (however simple) of knowing how to access the relevant field to each function rather than in the calling function. In this way, the caller can view all of the comparison functions as the same and do things like the map.

This selector seems too broad, and could be broken by unrelated future changes on the page - would try to grab a uniquely identifiable parent element (via id or data-test-id) to ensure this is looking at the right thing. Can do repeated .find()s if needed, e.g. wrapper.find({'data-test-id': 'some-parent-id'}).find(TextColumn)
nit: does this need to be function? Seems like it would suffice to just make this a const
nit: avoid relative

If we go with this for now (looks like the patchInProgress variable is not being returned), then please either set a time limit on this polling OR change the condition to be !== RUNNING || noChangesNeeded, where changes needed can be a function of diffing r and requestedRuntime. This catches the case where the update gets applied but we somehow fail to observe any kind of status change.
In the mocks, the text of the update button is different in each case. Fine if this gets tracked in the follow-up ticket though.

nodes.bodyText:
console.error                                                                                                                                                                        
    Warning: Each child in a list should have a unique "key" prop

Missing await on all these, leading to act() warnings in the test:
console.error                                                                                                                                                                        
    Warning: You seem to have overlapping act() calls, this is not supported. Be sure to await previous act() calls before making a new one.
